notes: Eighth generation DN8 (2019-present). FWD standard, AWD introduced 2023. N Line performance variant available. Modern GDI engines with dual-clutch and automatic transmissions. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Sonata article, January 2025 revision.

Seventh generation CN7 (2020-present). N-Line and Elantra N performance variants available. Front-wheel drive. Modern Smartstream engines with CVT or DCT transmissions. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Elantra article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 1.6L GDi I4 + electric motor (139 hp combined)
notes: Hybrid variant of seventh generation Elantra. 1.6L gasoline engine paired with electric motor, 6-speed DCT. Front-wheel drive. Lithium-ion polymer battery. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Elantra article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation NX4 (2020-present). Available in SWB and LWB wheelbases. 1.5L/1.6L/2.0L/2.5L gasoline engines. FWD and AWD options. 6-speed manual, 6-speed automatic, 7-speed DCT, 8-speed automatic transmissions. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Tucson article, January 2025 revision.
Fourth generation hybrid variant. 1.6L T-GDi engine with electric motor, 1.49 kWh lithium-ion battery. FWD and AWD options. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Tucson article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation plug-in hybrid. 1.6L T-GDi engine with electric motor, 13.8 kWh lithium-ion battery. AWD standard. Requires PHEV service expertise for high-voltage battery system. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Tucson article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation TM (2018-2023) and fifth generation MX5 (2023-present). FWD and AWD options. Gasoline engines from 2.0L turbo to 3.5L V6. Fifth generation discontinued diesel engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Santa Fe article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 1.6L Smartstream G1.6 T-GDi I4 turbo + electric motor
notes: Fourth generation hybrid variant. 1.6L turbocharged engine with electric motor. FWD and AWD options. Lithium-ion polymer battery. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Santa Fe article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 1.6L Smartstream G1.6 T-GDi I4 turbo + electric motor
notes: Fourth generation plug-in hybrid. 1.6L turbocharged engine with electric motor. AWD standard. High-voltage battery system requires PHEV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Santa Fe article, January 2025 revision.

First generation LX2 (2018-2025). Hyundai's largest passenger vehicle. 7-8 passenger seating. 3.5L or 3.8L V6 engines. FWD and AWD options. 8-speed automatic transmission. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Palisade article, January 2025 revision.

First generation (2017-2023) and second generation (2023-present). Subcompact crossover with 1.6L turbo or 2.0L engines. FWD and AWD options. Multiple transmission choices. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Kona article, January 2025 revision.

engines: Electric motor: 99 kW (134 hp) standard range, 150 kW (204 hp) long range
notes: All-electric variant. Standard range: 48.6 kWh battery (134 hp). Long range: 64.8 kWh battery (204 hp, 490 km range). Front-wheel drive. Requires EV-certified technicians for high-voltage system service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Kona article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 1.6L Kappa I4 + 32 kW electric motor (141 hp combined)
notes: First generation Ioniq (discontinued July 2022). 1.6L engine with 32 kW electric motor, 1.56 kWh lithium-ion polymer battery. 6-speed DCT. Front-wheel drive. Replaced by Ioniq 5/6. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Ioniq article, January 2025 revision.

First generation Ioniq Electric (discontinued July 2022). 100 kW electric motor, 38.3 kWh lithium-ion polymer battery, 170-mile EPA range. 7.2 kW AC charging. Replaced by Ioniq 5/6. Requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Ioniq article, January 2025 revision.

First generation Ioniq Plug-in Hybrid (discontinued July 2022). 1.6L engine with 44.5 kW electric motor, 8.9 kWh lithium-ion polymer battery, 29-mile electric range. Requires PHEV service expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Ioniq article, January 2025 revision.

All-electric crossover (launched March 2021). Battery options: 58 kWh, 72.6 kWh, 77.4 kWh. RWD (168-225 hp) and AWD (232-321 hp) variants. 800V architecture with 233 kW DC fast charging (10-80% in 18 minutes). Ioniq 5 N performance model: 601 hp (641 hp boost). Requires EV-certified technicians for 800V high-voltage system. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Ioniq 5 article, January 2025 revision.

All-electric sedan (production started July 2022). Battery options: 53 kWh standard range, 77.4 kWh long range. RWD standard range (149 hp), RWD long range (225 hp), AWD long range (321 hp). 800V architecture, 10-80% charge in 18 minutes. Up to 614 km (382 mi) range. Requires EV-certified technicians for 800V high-voltage system. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Ioniq 6 article, January 2025 revision.
